parts: The greatest wonders you beheld were the three pyramids of this city, the largest of which was built by the great pharaoh Khufu.
At Giza, you also beheld many of these flat-roofed, rectangular tombs. My companions tell me that many Old Kingdom rulers and lesser nobles lay in eternal repose within these structures.
Observing famine victims you disprove this Greek physician’s theory about the formation of the jaw. This physician popularized the theory of the humors and built upon Hippocrates’ work.
In this final book of the New Testament, John of Patmos recorded that the end of the world will culminate in the coming of the New Jerusalem and a final triumph over Satan.
Unfortunately for followers of this religious denomination, the world did not actually end in 1843 or 1844, leading to an experience termed “the great disappointment.”

According to followers of this religion, an antichrist figure named ad-Dajjal will wreak havoc upon the Earth before the Day of Judgement. The mischievous nations of Yajuj and Majuj will also be unleashed.

answers: The Jazz Singer <Other Fine Arts, KLu><ed. AB>
parts: One of the first silent films to achieve widespread success has a title translated as A Trip to [this location]. In this film, directed by George Méliès [[“may-lee-EZ”]], a group of travelers shoot a capsule into the face of this location.

Alongside Charlie Chaplin, this man was one of the biggest stars of the silent film era. A famous scene from Steamboat Bill, Jr. starring this deadpan actor shows the front of a house falling down on him.

The silent film era began to draw to a close with the release of this film, considered the first “talkie.” In it, the main character, an aspiring entertainer, says “wait a minute, you ain’t seen nothing yet” as his first spoken line.

answers: disulfide bridges [accept disulfide bonds, prompt on disulfide, persulfide, or SS-bond] <Biology, KLei><ed. KLei>
parts: Protein breathing involves movements of domains and this level of protein structure. This level of protein structure is mediated by hydrogen bonds and includes the alpha-helix and beta-sheet motifs.
While secondary structure is three-dimensional, primary structure is comprised of the linear sequence of these monomers. They have a carboxyl and a namesake -NH2 [["N-H-2”]] group.

Proteins with multiple of these structures barely exhibit increases in breathing in dilute solutions because these structures may brace or stiffen tertiary structure. They are formed from two cysteine [["sis-teen”]] residues.
This French composer of Daphnis et Chloé also wrote a work portraying a dancing infanta in the style of a Velazquez painting, Pavane for a Dead Princess.
Ravel famously got into a heated argument with conductor Arturo Toscanini about the tempo of this piece, his most famous composition. This piece features a repetitive snare drum ostinato.
This is the name of the third and final movement of Ravel’s piano composition Gaspard de la Nuit. He intended for this movement to be more difficult than Balakirev’s Islamey.

answers: Sleepy Hollow [accept “The Legend of Sleepy Hollow”]
Rip Van Winkle [accept either underlined portion] <Short Fiction/Other, AK><ed. OC>
parts: Name this town in the Catskill Mountains. One of its inhabitants, Doffue Martling, claims to have single- handedly destroyed a British ship during the Revolutionary War.
The “Legend of Sleepy Hollow” appears in this author’s The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon. He wrote about Mateo Ximenes in Tales of the Alhambra.
Another Irving work is about this title character, who wakes up from a twenty-year sleep to learn of the death of his wife and the occurrence of the American Revolution.

answers: death [accept poisoning; accept drinking hemlock] <Philosophy, AH><ed. JB>
parts: The Euthyphro, Meno, Apology, and Crito are all works that are written in this literary form, whose name derives from the central action between Socrates and his interlocutors.

The Euthyphro concerns itself with the discovery of this concept, which Socrates remarks is either loved by the gods because it causes the gods to love it, or loved by the gods because the gods love it.
Socrates is sentenced to this punishment during his trial in the Apology, after not explicitly denying the charge that he corrupted the youth of Athens.

answers: men [accept “Men, men, men!”] <Drama, AK and MX><ed. OC>
parts: Name this play, where Henry Higgins attempts to reform Eliza Doolittle by ridding her of her Cockney accent.
Pygmalion is a work by this Irish playwright, who also wrote about the title character quitting the Salvation Army in Major Barbara.
In Act III, after finding out about her son’s insensitive behavior with Eliza, Miss Higgins shouts this word three times repeatedly.
Name this German painter and printmaker who engraved a truncated rhombohedron and a magic square behind a winged figure in his Melencolia I.
This other engraver etched a tall tree in the foreground of his The Large Spruce. He also painted a tablet suspended in the sky over embattled troops in The Battle of Alexander at Issus.
Dürer and Altdorfer were both part of the German branch of this movement. This movement saw a “rebirth” in art and science following the Middle Ages.

answers: Krebs cycle [accept citric acid cycle, TCA cycle, or tricarboxylic acid cycle]
mitochondrion [or mitochondria] <Other Science, KLei and VS><ed. VS>
parts: Name this process which begins with the oxidation of acetyl-coA [["uh-seat-ill Co-A”]]. It follows glycolysis in aerobic respiration.
In the first step of the Krebs Cycle, acetyl-coA combines with this molecule to form citrate.
While glycolysis occurs in the cytoplasm, the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain occur in the matrix of this organelle, which generates most of a cell’s ATP.
Name this novel that ends with the unveiling of a statue made in the image of the title German explorer.
Voss is a novel by Patrick White, who often utilized this narrative mode that interweaves the narrator’s thoughts and feelings with the actual events of the novel.
The aforementioned Voss tried to cross the dry Outback region of this country, White’s country of origin. The author of Schindler's Ark, Thomas Kearney, also originated from this country.

answers: Siege of Charleston <American History, AK and JP><ed. JB>
parts: Name this general who led Britain through the Southern Campaign of the Revolutionary War, leading to victories at Camden and Guilford Courthouse.

Cornwallis is most famous for losing this battle where defensive points were held at Redoubts Nine and Ten. French forces under the Comte de Rochambeau and the Marquis de Lafayette assisted the winning side in this battle.

George Washington denied the British traditional honors after Yorktown due to the British denial of American honors at this battle, which saw the first combat by Comte D’Estaing’s Haitian expeditionary force.
Name these structures, which are stable at certain magic numbers. Their namesake binding energy arises from the mass defect they possess.
This force is what holds the nucleus together. It is named for being the most powerful of the fundamental forces at close distances.

The liquid drop model was proposed by this scientist, who theorized that alpha decay was caused by particles quantum tunneling out of the nucleus. Alpher, Bethe, and this man wrote a paper on Big Bang nucleosynthesis.

answers: universal single-payer healthcare [prompt on healthcare, universal healthcare, or national healthcare]
Medicare [do not accept “Medicaid”] <Current Events, AK><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: Identify this system, where the government collects taxes to pay and cover medical expenses for all of its residents. This alleviates the need for individuals to obtain private insurance.

This longest serving African-American congressman from Michigan introduced a national single-payer system bill every year since 2003. He resigned in December 2017 after allegations of sexual harassment.
A type of single-payer healthcare system is this national health insurance program, which Conyers sought to expand. It provides health insurance for Americans 65 and older.

answers: train [accept Train to Busan] <Pop Culture/Mixed Academic, KLu><ed. KLu and AK>
parts: In June 2018, this group’s album Love Yourself: Tear became the first KPop album to hit number one on the Billboard 200. This boy band’s name has a name that translates from Korean as “bulletproof boy scouts.”
The fictional KPop group K/DA released the song “POP/STARS” at the World Championships of this online game in South Korea. This online battle arena game was developed by Riot Games.
In 2015, a Korean movie about a zombie outbreak was titled [this object] to Busan. Another Korean-produced movie, Snowpiercer, is set on one of these objects and ends with its destruction.

Name this ethnic group, whose Kingdoms were targeted by the Fulani Jihad, a conquest detailed in Muhammad Bello’s The Wages of The Fortunate. The Sokoto Caliphate supplanted many of these peoples’ Kingdoms.
The Hausa live primarily in this modern day nation, whose other large ethnic groups include the Yoruba and Igbo [[ee-bo]].
The Sokoto Caliphate practiced this branch of Islam. Usman dan Fodio, Sokoto’s founder, was a leader of this branch of Islam, which makes up 90% of the world’s Muslims.
Name this city. A poem that describes an “old yellow pair” who “eat beans mostly” appears in a poetry collection that illustrates a fictional portrayal of this city, A Street in Bronzeville.
The author of A Street in Bronzeville, Gwendolyn Brooks, became the first African American to win this prize for poetry in 1950. In 2018, Kendrick Lamar won this prize for music for his album DAMN.
This other poet described Chicago as a “Hog Butcher for the World” and a “Stacker of Wheat.” He also declared “Pile the bodies high at Austerlitz and Waterloo” in his poem “Grass.”
Name this type of organic compound. Members of this family of organic compounds are characterized by the formula R-O-R’ [["R-Oh-R prime”]].
This general type of reaction forms ethers from an alcohol and an organic halide. It sometimes involves catalysis by salts such as silver oxide.

The crown ether 18-crown-6 is used as a catalyst in Williamson ether synthesis due to its ability to sequester ions of this metal. This metal lies below sodium on the periodic table, and a good source of it is bananas.
The Golden Fleece came from the ram which carried Helle and this other son of Athamas and Nephele over the Black Sea. While Helle fell off and died, this youth was able to arrive safely at Colchis.
Phrixus was forced to leave Boeotia due to the machinations of Ino, the daughter of this founder of Thebes who sowed dragon’s teeth to create the Spartoi.
After arriving at Colchis, Phrixus sacrificed the ram and gave the Fleece to King Aeëtes, who hung it in a holy grove of this Greek god of war.

answers: Nantes [accept Edict of Nantes] <European History, EL><ed. OC>
parts: Name this region where royalist forces led by generals like Henri de la Rochejaquelein [[“roash-ja-kuh-lan”]] staged a bloody uprising against the newly instituted government in 1793.
The War in the Vendée took place during this larger conflict that saw the toppling of Louis XVI and the Ancien [[ahn-see-EN]] Régime.
Much of the War in the Vendée was centered on this city on the banks of the Loire. A law named for this city gave religious protection to Huguenots and was revoked by the Edict of Fontainebleau.
